title: Magic resistance (monster)
data:
In *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*, monsters have some degree of innate **magic resistance**, also known as **monster MR**. Monsters' magic resistance allows them to resist various attacks, generally of a "magical" nature. It is handled by the resist() function—if a monster successfully resists an attack, it takes roughly half damage.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) Players cannot ever gain monster-style resistance, e.g. through [polymorph](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph"), and must instead rely upon [magic cancellation](/wiki/Magic_cancellation "Magic cancellation") and [magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance").

Monster magic resistance is separate from the [magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance") property provided by various worn or carried [items](/wiki/Item "Item"), which some monsters such as [gray dragons](/wiki/Gray_dragon "Gray dragon") and [Angels](/wiki/Angel "Angel") also have intrinsically; this form of "player-style" magic resistance does not affect [taming](/wiki/Taming "Taming") and [conflict](/wiki/Conflict "Conflict"), but renders [polymorph traps](/wiki/Polymorph_trap "Polymorph trap") ineffective. Neither type of magic resistance will protect monsters from level teleporters.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Description](#Description)

- [2 List of effects subject to monster MR](#List_of_effects_subject_to_monster_MR)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 Messages](#Messages)

- [5 Variants](#Variants)

  - [5.1 NetHack Fourk](#NetHack_Fourk)
  - [5.2 FIQHack](#FIQHack)
  - [5.3 xNetHack](#xNetHack)
  - [5.4 EvilHack](#EvilHack)

- [6 References](#References)

## Description

MR is given as a number from 0 to 100. This is frequently given as a percentage, although this is not entirely accurate. The chance of a monster resisting is given as follows:

```
Chance = MR/(100 + (attack level) - (defense level))[2]
```

which is only equal to MR as a percentage when attack and defense level are equal. Zero MR monsters will never resist.

Attack level is calculated as follows, where the defense level is the [monster level](/wiki/Monster_level "Monster level") of the target, which has a maximum of 50:

| Source                                                                                | Attack level   |
| ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | -------------- |
| [spell](/wiki/Spellcasting "Spellcasting")                                            | Caster's level |
| [wand](/wiki/Wand "Wand"), [polytrap](/wiki/Polytrap "Polytrap")[\[3\]](#cite_note-3) | 12             |
| [tool](/wiki/Tool "Tool")                                                             | 10             |
| [weapon](/wiki/Weapon "Weapon")                                                       | 10             |
| [scroll](/wiki/Scroll "Scroll")                                                       | 9              |
| [potion](/wiki/Potion "Potion")                                                       | 6              |
| [ring](/wiki/Ring "Ring")                                                             | 5              |

All this also determines the chance that monsters (including [pets](/wiki/Pet "Pet") resist conflict; conflict from the [Sceptre of Might](/wiki/Sceptre_of_Might "Sceptre of Might") is treated the same as the [ring of conflict](/wiki/Ring_of_conflict "Ring of conflict") for this purpose.

## List of effects subject to monster MR

A user has suggested improving this page or section as follows:

*"A list of all effects subject to monster mr, and/or confirmation that all those effects mention they are subject to it and link here."*

## Strategy

Monster magic resistance generally determines what strategies are effective against certain monsters - for example, the [Riders](/wiki/Riders "Riders") have complete monster magic resistance, but & [Pestilence](/wiki/Pestilence "Pestilence") and & [Famine](/wiki/Famine "Famine") can be subjected to [level drain](/wiki/Level_drain "Level drain"), making it possible for magical effects to work on them if their level is drained enough; & [Death](/wiki/Death_\(monster\) "Death (monster)") is completely resistant to drain life.

## Messages

- <[Foo](/wiki/Foo "Foo")> resists!

  A monster resisted an attack; this is shown only in some cases.

## Variants

Some variants change the monster magic resistance stats for certain monsters that are included from vanilla *NetHack* or other variants, and may additionally change the name to further distinguish it from the magic resistance property.

### NetHack Fourk

In [NetHack Fourk](/wiki/NetHack_Fourk "NetHack Fourk"), the stat is referred to as **willpower**.

### FIQHack

In [FIQHack](/wiki/FIQHack "FIQHack"), this stat is also called **willpower**, with the attacker bonus from wands dependent on the [wand skill](/wiki/Wands_Balance_Patch "Wands Balance Patch").

### xNetHack

[xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack") calls this stat **magic saving throw**.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), this stat is referred to as **magic saving throw** in the monster lookup; various monsters added from *NetHack* and other variants also have their magic saving throw improved.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/zap.c in NetHack 3.6.0, line 4802](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.0_Release/src/zap.c#L4802)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/zap.c in NetHack 3.6.0, line 4842](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.0_Release/src/zap.c#L4842)
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/trap.c in NetHack 3.6.0, line 2588](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.0_Release/src/trap.c#L2588)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.0. Click here for more information.](/images/d/d6/Nh360-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.0. Click here for more information.")

**This page may need to be updated for the [current version](/wiki/Current_version "Current version") of *NetHack*.**

It may contain text specific to [NetHack 3.6.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.0 "NetHack 3.6.0"). Information on this page may be out of date.

**Editors:** After reviewing this page and making necessary edits, please change the {{nethack-360}} tag to the current version's tag or {{noversion}} as appropriate.
html:
Magic resistance (monster)

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search

In NetHack, monsters have some degree of innate magic resistance, also known as monster MR. Monsters' magic resistance allows them to resist various attacks, generally of a "magical" nature. It is handled by the resist() function—if a monster successfully resists an attack, it takes roughly half damage.[1] Players cannot ever gain monster-style resistance, e.g. through polymorph, and must instead rely upon magic cancellation and magic resistance.

Monster magic resistance is separate from the magic resistance property provided by various worn or carried items, which some monsters such as gray dragons and Angels also have intrinsically; this form of "player-style" magic resistance does not affect taming and conflict, but renders polymorph traps ineffective. Neither type of magic resistance will protect monsters from level teleporters.

Contents

  • 1 Description
  • 2 List of effects subject to monster MR
  • 3 Strategy
  • 4 Messages
  • 5 Variants
    • 5.1 NetHack Fourk
    • 5.2 FIQHack
    • 5.3 xNetHack
    • 5.4 EvilHack
  • 6 References

Description

MR is given as a number from 0 to 100. This is frequently given as a percentage, although this is not entirely accurate. The chance of a monster resisting is given as follows: 

Chance = MR/(100 + (attack level) - (defense level))[2]

which is only equal to MR as a percentage when attack and defense level are equal. Zero MR monsters will never resist.

Attack level is calculated as follows, where the defense level is the monster level of the target, which has a maximum of 50:

Source Attack level
spell Caster's level
wand, polytrap[3] 12
tool 10
weapon 10
scroll 9
potion 6
ring 5

All this also determines the chance that monsters (including pets resist conflict; conflict from the Sceptre of Might is treated the same as the ring of conflict for this purpose.

List of effects subject to monster MR

A user has suggested improving this page or section as follows:

"A list of all effects subject to monster mr, and/or confirmation that all those effects mention they are subject to it and link here."

Strategy

Monster magic resistance generally determines what strategies are effective against certain monsters - for example, the Riders have complete monster magic resistance, but & Pestilence and & Famine can be subjected to level drain, making it possible for magical effects to work on them if their level is drained enough; & Death is completely resistant to drain life.

Messages

<Foo> resists!
A monster resisted an attack; this is shown only in some cases.

Variants

Some variants change the monster magic resistance stats for certain monsters that are included from vanilla NetHack or other variants, and may additionally change the name to further distinguish it from the magic resistance property.

NetHack Fourk

In NetHack Fourk, the stat is referred to as willpower.

FIQHack

In FIQHack, this stat is also called willpower, with the attacker bonus from wands dependent on the wand skill.

xNetHack

xNetHack calls this stat magic saving throw.

EvilHack

In EvilHack, this stat is referred to as magic saving throw in the monster lookup; various monsters added from NetHack and other variants also have their magic saving throw improved.

References

  1. ↑ src/zap.c in NetHack 3.6.0, line 4802
  2. ↑ src/zap.c in NetHack 3.6.0, line 4842
  3. ↑ src/trap.c in NetHack 3.6.0, line 2588

This page may need to be updated for the current version of NetHack.

It may contain text specific to NetHack 3.6.0. Information on this page may be out of date.

Editors: After reviewing this page and making necessary edits, please change the {{nethack-360}} tag to the current version's tag or {{noversion}} as appropriate.

rawPage:
In ''[[NetHack]]'', monsters have some degree of innate '''magic resistance''', also known as '''monster MR'''. Monsters' magic resistance allows them to resist various attacks, generally of a "magical" nature. It is handled by the resist() function—if a monster successfully resists an attack, it takes roughly half damage.{{refsrc|src/zap.c|4802|nethack=3.6.0}} Players cannot ever gain monster-style resistance, e.g. through [[polymorph]], and must instead rely upon [[magic cancellation]] and [[magic resistance]].

Monster magic resistance is separate from the [[magic resistance]] property provided by various worn or carried [[item]]s, which some monsters such as [[gray dragon]]s and [[Angel]]s also have intrinsically; this form of "player-style" magic resistance does not affect [[taming]] and [[conflict]], but renders [[polymorph trap]]s ineffective. Neither type of magic resistance will protect monsters from level teleporters.

==Description==
MR is given as a number from 0 to 100. This is frequently given as a percentage, although this is not entirely accurate. The chance of a monster resisting is given as follows:

 Chance = MR/(100 + (attack level) - (defense level)){{refsrc|src/zap.c|4842|nethack=3.6.0}}

which is only equal to MR as a percentage when attack and defense level are equal. Zero MR monsters will never resist.

Attack level is calculated as follows, where the defense level is the [[monster level]] of the target, which has a maximum of 50:

{|class="prettytable"
! Source
! Attack level
|-
| [[spellcasting|spell]]
| Caster's level

| [[wand]], [[polytrap]]{{refsrc|src/trap.c|2588|nethack=3.6.0}}

All this also determines the chance that monsters (including [[pet]]s resist conflict; conflict from the [[Sceptre of Might]] is treated the same as the [[ring of conflict]] for this purpose.

==Strategy==
Monster magic resistance generally determines what strategies are effective against certain monsters - for example, the [[Riders]] have complete monster magic resistance, but {{monsymlink|Pestilence}} and {{monsymlink|Famine}} can be subjected to [[level drain]], making it possible for magical effects to work on them if their level is drained enough; {{monsymlink|Death}} is completely resistant to drain life.

==Messages==
{{message|<[[Foo]]> resists!|A monster resisted an attack; this is shown only in some cases.}}

==Variants==
Some variants change the monster magic resistance stats for certain monsters that are included from vanilla ''NetHack'' or other variants, and may additionally change the name to further distinguish it from the magic resistance property.

===NetHack Fourk===
In [[NetHack Fourk]], the stat is referred to as '''willpower'''.

===FIQHack===
In [[FIQHack]], this stat is also called '''willpower''', with the attacker bonus from wands dependent on the [[Wands Balance Patch|wand skill]].

===xNetHack===
[[xNetHack]] calls this stat '''magic saving throw'''.

===EvilHack===
In [[EvilHack]], this stat is referred to as '''magic saving throw''' in the monster lookup; various monsters added from ''NetHack'' and other variants also have their magic saving throw improved.
